author: @lennarthallberg9918
text:
I strongly suspect that Qatari money has a lot to do with the BBC`s, CNN`s, France 24`s and many other big news outlets false propaganda about Israel and their propaganda for Iran and their violent proxies. Also BBC and CNN  "forgot" to say that Hamas not only starved their hostages deliberately, but Hamas has also deliberately starved all ordinary people living in Gaza during their whole war against Israel.

And that Hamas has also starved young Gazans deliberately to be able to showcase them to the international media in order to "prove" their false claims about Israel and starvation in Gaza, as we all have seen also here at the BBC. Then Hamas changed tactics and BBC showcased young seriously ill and /or undernourished children Hamas had deliberately starved for their propaganda purposes.

After Hamas` change of tactics the BBC also stopped showing fat Gazan "mothers" "crying" in their news about famine. The whole international media, including BBC and CNN, must have known all that perfectly well. Looks like the whole international mainstream media has hired dishonest people like CNN`s Christiane Amanpour, people who are ready to do practically everything and anything in order to get and to keep their well paying jobs.

I find Hamas`s all actions and all the methods Hamas have used for propaganda purposes more than repulsive. Hamas is more than clearly guilty of deliberately committed crimes against humanity. The vast majority of the international mainstream media, including BBC and CNN , is in my opinion guilty of protecting Hamas with their biased and false propaganda for Hamas and against Israel.

The New York Timesâ€™s Tom Friedman and CNN`s Christiane Amanpour are the two worst pro-Hamas propagandists in my opinion. They work for news outlets that the whole international media use as their "source" about Israel and Gaza, including the BBC. Both news outlets should finally stop their false propaganda about Israel and stop also their propaganda for Iran and for their violent proxies.

Hamas has already lost their fight against Israel, so why not demand them to lift a white flag to finally stop that total madness they have caused for all ordinary people living in Gaza, instead of falsely blaming Israel for what Hamas has caused and still is causing in Gaza. 

Israel can't possibly win the massive propaganda war against them, but Israel could win the actual war against them. And that is what in the end matters the most.

author: @lennarthallberg9918
text:
The BBC should finally stop their pro-Hamas propaganda

The ordinary people living in Gaza have been in reality stripped of every piece of their humanity by Hamas and their cruel leaders. How is Hamas` terrorism different from ISIS` terrorism from their victims point of view? Is Hamas acting more nicely towards their victims than ISIS did?

The only real difference between ISIS`s terrorism and Hamas`s terrorism is that Hamas portrays itself as defending Palestinian national aspirations and that ISIS did not use that same excuse for their terrorism. Simply by looking at the facts one can say that the ordinary people living in Gaza don`t matter much for Hamas` leaders, regardless of their age or medical condition.

Hamas is not only using people they kidnapped from Israel as their hostages. Hamas also uses all ordinary people living in Gaza as their hostages. Hamas portrays itself as defending Palestinian national aspirations and Jerusalem's Muslim holy sites, when in reality Hamas is just a cruel terrorist organization.

The only thing Hamas` leaders care about is their own twisted ideology that is solely based upon cruel violence and terror. And making as much money as they possibly can for themselves that way. The fact of the matter is that if Hamas would care about the ordinary people who live in Gaza, they would have surrendered unconditionally and released all their hostages already long ago. Hamas is a cruel terrorist organization.

Hamas leaders don`t care one bit about what happens to ordinary people, no matter where they live or what religion they represent. Hamas` leaders decided to continue holding their hostages and continue to fight against Israel. Those two Hamas leader's decisions proves that they don`t care one bit about the disastrous consequences that their decisions have for all ordinary people living in Gaza.

That means in practice that the well-being of the ordinary people who live in Gaza does not matter one bit for Hamas` leaders. One has to be a Hamas member or a Hamas supporter not to realize all those very simple facts about Hamas and their leaders. Or a total fool.

High time also for the BBC to get these simple facts about Hamas.

The people of Palestine certainly rejected this decision, but the Palestinians are still emerging from occupation, so there is no way out, so they were forced to submit to this reality, and with regard to that group that says that Palestine sold its land  Palestine did not sell its land, but there were two types:
The first type: The elderly who were not aware of politics, when a Zionist asked them to buy land for a double amount, agreed, but they did not know what would happen because they were not aware of politics.
The second category: The majority of them were not Palestinians, but from different countries

text:
The BBC's online Middle East editor, Raffi Berg, an Israeli Mossad agent, working for the BBC, supposedly an impartial public broadcasterâ€¦

Berg has almost complete control of the British broadcaster's online coverage of Israel's war on Gaza and is ensuring that all events are reported with a pro-Israel bias, according to a new report published on 28 December by Drop Site News.

"This guy's entire job is to water down everything that's too critical of Israel," one former BBC journalist said.

Drop Site News spoke to 13 current and former staffers who stated that the BBC's coverage consistently devalues Palestinian life, ignores Israeli atrocities, and creates a false equivalence in an entirely unbalanced conflict.

Another BBC journalist said Berg plays a key role in a broader BBC culture of "systematic Israeli propaganda." 

"How much power he has is wild," said another journalist.

"There was an extreme fear at the BBC, that if you ever wanted to do anything about Israel or Palestine, editors would say: 'If you want to pitch something, you have to go through Raffi and get his signoff," another journalist explained.

In one case, Berg downplayed Amnesty International's accusation that Israel is committing genocide in Gaza.

Berg chose a headline that stated, "Israel rejects 'fabricated' claims of genocide," to describe the Amnesty report and failed to post the story for 12 hours after it was written to suppress its online reach.

author: @bFosterree
text:
Why are they palestinian prisoners and not palestinian hostages? To be clear, most of these Palestinian â€œprisonersâ€ are held under administrative detention. According to human rights organizations, Israelâ€™s dual legal system constitutes apartheid, as it enforces separate and unequal treatment based on nationality and ethnicity. Under this system, Palestinians, including children, are often detained without charge or trial under administrative detention orders. As of December 1, 2024, Israeli authorities held 2,873 Palestinians in administrative detention, marking a three-decade high. Amnesty International has documented the systematic use of torture and degrading treatment of Palestinian detainees, including beatings, stress positions, and denial of medical care, all of which violate international law.

Given this context, these detainees are not conventional prisoners and itâ€™s better to describe them as hostages. This distinction is critical, as it challenges the implicit narrative that Palestinians in Israeli prisons have all been convicted of criminal offenses, when in reality, many are held without charge or trial. Reframing their status as hostages better reflects the power dynamics at play and highlights the broader context of occupation and human rights violations by Israel.

Since you referred to the Israelis in the exchange as hostages, it seems only fair to refer to the Palestinians in the same manner. Failure to do so is a double-standard.

author: @PeterMsk2023
text:
The Unwitting Failure of Ethnicityâ€¦

From the perspective of unwitting ethnicity failure, Israelâ€™s conduct following the belated ceasefire in the Middle East exposes a profound moral dissonance between its proclaimed spiritual heritage and its present political behaviour. The governmentâ€™s refusal to deploy heavy excavation machinery to recover the remains of hostagesâ€”alongside tens of thousands of Palestinians still buried under the 85% of Gaza reduced to rubbleâ€”amounts not only to administrative neglect, but to a symbolic act of indifference, rubbing salt into the still-open wounds of Arab-Israeli relations.

Worse still, the continued restriction of humanitarian aid and the cynical use of food as a weapon of control reflect a dangerous pattern: a nation once defined by its historical suffering has learned to wield suffering as an instrument of power. This tragic inversion is not mere political misjudgmentâ€”it is the manifestation of an unprocessed ethnic trauma, where collective fear and inherited grievance distort moral vision.

In this sense, many 21st-century Israelisâ€”often unconsciouslyâ€”have become victims of their own mythic narrative. By over-interpreting the biblical idea of a â€œGreater Israel,â€ they mistake spiritual allegory for territorial entitlement. The ancient texts that once served as ethical mirrors for self-refinement have been reduced to literal claims of supremacy, betraying their original moral intent.

When Netanyahu's Zionist government elevates this literalism to state policy, it effectively implements a collective moral inversionâ€”reenacting its own past oppression while blaming others. As a result, what we witness is not faith, but fear; not prophecy, but pathologyâ€”a political form of historical post-traumatic stress disorder. This is the tragedy of a nation seeking redemption through rule, yet risking the loss of the moral soul that once determined its survival. In February 2025, Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Galant admitted that the IDF followed "Hannibal's instructions" during the Gaza Warâ€”preferring to kill Israelis rather than be taken hostage, and prioritising the elimination of the enemy over the rescue of hostages during raids into enemy territory. This is a vivid example of how a Zionist-driven Israeli government has fallen into the trap of tribal survival.

Ultimately, history teaches that any people who fail to transform their trauma into wisdom will repeat it upon others. When pain remains unexamined, it hardens into ideology; when fear becomes identity, compassion disappears. True national maturity arises not from victory or vengeance, but from the courage to transcend inherited wounds. Only by recognising this shared human frailty can both Israelis and Arabsâ€”and indeed all nationsâ€”move toward a peace grounded not in dominance, but in dignity.

author: @AlemayehuSiffir21
text:
Interesting newsâ¤

And, I have additional comments for Dear President Donald J. Trump,

I hope this message finds you well. I am reaching out with a heartfelt request for your esteemed leadership to address critical issues concerning Ethiopia, particularly regarding the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) and the historical access to the Asseb port, as well as to propose solutions to end Ethiopiaâ€™s internal conflicts.
The Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD):
The GERD is a vital project for Ethiopia, symbolizing national pride and a pathway to sustainable development through clean energy and economic growth. However, ongoing disputes with Egypt over the damâ€™s management have escalated tensions in the region. I respectfully urge you to encourage Egyptâ€™s leadership to adopt a more collaborative approach in discussions about the GERD. A balanced dialogue that respects Ethiopiaâ€™s right to harness its natural resources while addressing downstream concerns could pave the way for a mutually beneficial agreement. Your influence could help de-escalate tensions and promote a spirit of cooperation among Nile Basin countries.
Restoration of Asseb Port Access:
Historically, the Asseb port was a critical lifeline for Ethiopiaâ€™s trade and economic stability. Since Eritreaâ€™s independence, Ethiopiaâ€™s landlocked status has posed significant challenges to its economy. I kindly request your support in advocating for renewed access to the Asseb port for Ethiopia, potentially through diplomatic negotiations with Eritrea. Restoring Ethiopiaâ€™s access to this port would enhance regional trade, reduce economic strain, and foster stability in the Horn of Africa. Your voice in supporting Ethiopiaâ€™s historical and economic ties to Asseb could be a game-changer for the region.
Solutions to Ethiopiaâ€™s Internal Conflicts:
Ethiopia is grappling with internal conflicts that threaten its unity and progress. To address these challenges and promote lasting peace, I propose the following solutions:
Inclusive National Dialogue: Encourage Ethiopiaâ€™s government to initiate a transparent and inclusive national dialogue involving all ethnic groups, political factions, and civil society. This platform could address grievances, promote reconciliation, and build trust among communities.
Ceasefire Agreements: Advocate for immediate ceasefires in conflict zones, particularly in regions like Tigray, Amhara, and Oromia, to create space for humanitarian aid and peace talks.
Economic Development Programs: Support investments in job creation, infrastructure, and education to address root causes of unrest, such as poverty and marginalization. International partnerships, potentially facilitated by your influence, could help fund these initiatives.
Strengthening Governance: Promote reforms that enhance democratic institutions, ensure equitable representation, and protect human rights, fostering a sense of unity and shared purpose among Ethiopiaâ€™s diverse population.
International Mediation: Endorse the involvement of neutral international mediators, such as the African Union or United Nations, to facilitate peace negotiations and ensure impartiality.
Your leadership and global influence could play a pivotal role in guiding Ethiopia toward peace and prosperity. By addressing the GERD dispute, advocating for Asseb port access, and supporting solutions to internal conflicts, you have the opportunity to help Ethiopia overcome its challenges and strengthen regional stability.
Thank you for considering this appeal. I am confident that your wisdom and commitment to global peace can make a profound difference. ðŸ™ðŸ™ðŸ™

With utmost respect,
Alemayehu Siffir Argawu (PhD Candidate)
Andhra University, India

author: @andreg3349
text:
Brothers and sisters, warriors for justice, voices for the voiceless:

We stand today at a crossroads of history. We are witnessing not a moment of decline, but of awakening. We see empires â€” built on lies, corruption, fear, and division â€” falter under their own weight. The structures that once seemed impregnable are cracking. And we â€” the people â€” hold the power to push them further, to make them crumble, to build something new from their ruins.

They fear our unity. They rely on our silence. But when we speak, when we act, when we refuse to relent, their scaffolding begins to shake. Their illusions of invincibility are just that â€” illusions.

Today I call on you: rise up in solidarity. Let your anger burn with purpose. Let your fear be transformed into resolve. Let your voice echo beyond the walls of oppression.

Because they count on us to be divided. They rely on us to despair. But we will not give them that gift.

We must expose the lies, reveal the hidden hands, and tear away the masks. We must demand accountability, transparency, justice. We must hold every corrupt leader to the light. We must dismantle the systems that prey on the vulnerable. We must uproot the greed that feeds on suffering.

But this is not a distant hope â€” this is a task for us, here and now. You who listen: your courage matters. Your solidarity matters. Your refusal to walk away matters.

Every chant, every protest, every act of resistance, no matter how small, is a blow against the illusion of power. Every truth told against the tides of deception becomes a pillar in a new foundation. Every hand extended across divides becomes a bridge of humanity.

They would have us believe we are powerless. They would have us believe we are isolated. They would have us believe it is too late.

We say: No. We are already in motion. We are already many. We are already unstoppable.

So we march. We shout. We organize. We resist. We create. We heal. We rebuild.

And when future generations ask: where were you when the empire cracked? â€” we will say: we were there. We fought. We rose. We built something better.

Let them tremble â€” for the power has always been ours. Let them fall â€” for their time is ending. And let us rise â€” for the dawn of justice is ours to shape.

Rise, awaken, act.

We are the reckoning.

text:
Reminds me of this paragraph by Chris Hedges the NYTs Senior Israel correspondence for like 10 years:

The brazenness of Israeli lies stunned those of us who reported from Gaza. It did not matter if we had seen the Israeli attack, including the shooting of unarmed Palestinians. It did not matter how many witnesses we interviewed. It did not matter what photographic and forensic evidence we obtained. Israel lied. Small lies. Big lies. Huge lies. These lies came reflexively and instantly from the Israeli military, Israeli politicians and Israeli media. They were amplified by Israelâ€™s well-oiled propaganda machine and repeated with a cloying sincerity on international news outlets.
Israel engages in the kinds of jaw-dropping lies that characterize despotic regimes. It does not deform the truth, it inverts it. It paints a picture that is diametrically opposed to reality. Those of us who have covered the occupied territories have run into Israelâ€™s Alice-in-Wonderland narratives, which we dutifully insert into our stories â€” required under the rules of American journalism â€” although we know they are untrue.

text: My compassion for Israel has waned tremendously over this action in Gaza. The Idea that this attack has in any way diminish the desire for Palestinian nationhood needs to be reflected upon as similar events against the Jewish people just 80 years ago resulted in a Jewish state.  While some will thump their chests saying military might was the answer and others pursue a Nobel prize after finding themselves clearly on the opposite side of international opinion,  it will be will the people of these two nations who ultimately need to find a way to, not only peacefully live together, but to thrive in a mutually beneficial and respectful arrangement.  It is out of character for humans to accept their part in war, even harder to forgive, but to continue down this historic path is a recipe for mutual destruction  The true winners and peace makers are those on both sides of the conflict who see a better future working together and pursue that outcome.

text:
1. Before Israel, there was a British mandate, not a Palestinian state.  
 2. Before the British Mandate, there was the Ottoman Empire, not a Palestinian state.
 3. Before the Ottoman Empire, there was the Islamic state of the Mamluks of Egypt, not a Palestinian state.
 4. Before the Islamic state of the Mamluks of Egypt, there was the Ayubid Arab-Kurdish Empire, not a Palestinian state.
 5. Before the Ayubid Empire, there was the Frankish and Christian Kingdom of Jerusalem, not a Palestinian state.
 6. Before the Kingdom of Jerusalem, there was the Umayyad and Fatimid empires, not a Palestinian state.  
 7. Before the Umayyad and Fatimid empires, there was the Byzantine empire, not a Palestinian state.
 8. Before the Byzantine Empire, there were the Sassanids, not a Palestinian state.
 9. Before the Sassanid Empire, there was the Byzantine Empire, not a Palestinian state.
 10. Before the Byzantine Empire, there was the Roman Empire, not a Palestinian state.
 11. Before the Roman Empire, there was the Hasmonean state, not a Palestinian state.
 12. Before the Hasmonean state, there was the Seleucid, not a Palestinian state.  
 13. Before the Seleucid empire, there was the empire of Alexander the Great, not a Palestinian state.
 14. Before the empire of Alexander the Great, there was the Persian empire, not a Palestinian state.  
 15. Before the Persian Empire, there was the Babylonian Empire, not a Palestinian state.
 16. Before the Babylonian Empire, there were the Kingdoms of Israel and Judah, not a Palestinian state.  
 17. Before the Kingdoms of Israel and Judah, there was the Kingdom of Israel, not a Palestinian state.  
 18. Before the kingdom of Israel, there was the theocracy of the twelve tribes of Israel, not a Palestinian state.  
 19. Before the theocracy of the twelve tribes of Israel, there was an agglomeration of independent Canaanite city-kingdoms, not a Palestinian state.
  20. Actually, in this piece of land there has been everything, EXCEPT A PALESTINIAN STATE

author: @JellieBae-d7y
text:
The Profiteering System Behind the Conflict
From 2018 until just before the October 7th attacks, approximately $30 million per month flowed to Hamas through Qatarâ€”totaling nearly $2 billion. This arrangement was facilitated through coordination between U.S. officials (including a 2018 letter from Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin assuring Qatar the payments wouldn't be considered terrorism financing), Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, and Qatari officials who provided Hamas an office in Doha (New York Times, December 10, 2023).
Netanyahu's Strategy: Strengthen Hamas to Prevent Peace
In 2019, Netanyahu publicly stated: "Anyone who wants to thwart the establishment of a Palestinian state has to support bolstering Hamas." This wasn't a secretâ€”it was deliberate policy to prevent Palestinian unity by keeping Hamas strong and preventing a two-state solution. Israeli intelligence warned multiple times (2019, 2020) that funds were being diverted to Hamas's military wing, but Netanyahu continued the payments anyway (New York Times, December 10, 2023).
Follow the Money: Who Profits From War?
Members of Congress hold millions in defense contractor stocks and directly profit when conflicts escalate. After October 7th, defense stocks surged: RTX Corporation jumped 9%, Lockheed Martin rose 9%, and Northrop Grumman gained 11% (Newsweek, November 2, 2023). Elected officials who vote on military aid packages while holding these stocks face an obvious conflict of interestâ€”they financially benefit from prolonging war rather than pursuing peace.
Construction Companies Betting on Destruction
Israeli construction firms have seen massive stock gains during active combat:
Shikun & Binui: +100% annual gain, +29% in October 2025 alone
Other construction stocks showing similar patterns
Why would construction stocks surge during a war? Because investors are betting on reconstruction contracts. The system profits from a cycle: destroy infrastructure, then profit from rebuilding it.
Displacement as Business Opportunity
Eco Buildings Group, a modular housing company with operations in Sudan, saw a 380% stock surge coinciding with Israeli officials' proposals for Palestinian "voluntary emigration" to Sudan. This suggests investors are anticipating profits from mass displacementâ€”treating ethnic cleansing as a business opportunity.
Energy: The Hidden Motive
In August 2023â€”just two months before October 7thâ€”Chevron approved a $429 million expansion of Israel's Leviathan gas field to increase production capacity. Meanwhile, Gaza's Marine gas field (estimated worth: billions) remains deliberately undeveloped. Keeping Gaza unstable prevents Palestinian energy independence and eliminates competition for Israeli gas companies.
Hamas Leadership Profits Too
The U.S. Treasury confirmed Hamas operates a "secret investment portfolio" worth hundreds of millions through companies in Turkey, Sudan, and Algeria. Hamas leadership lives in luxury in Qatar while Gazans suffer under blockade. They divert humanitarian aid for military purposes and personal enrichment.
The International Court's Findings
The International Court of Justice issued three provisional measures (January, March, and May 2024) finding a "plausible risk of genocide" in Gaza. In September 2024, a UN Commission concluded that "Israel has committed genocide in Gaza" (UN OHCHR, September 16, 2024). Over 46,000 Palestinians have been killed, 1.9 million displaced, and 60% of infrastructure destroyed.
The Bottom Line
This isn't about picking sides between Israelis and Palestiniansâ€”both civilian populations are victims. This is about exposing a system where:
Political leaders on multiple sides financially benefit from conflict
Defense contractors profit from weapons sales
Construction companies profit from destruction and rebuilding
Energy companies profit from preventing Palestinian development
Hamas leadership profits while their own people starve
The cycle works like this: Fund instability â†’ conflict erupts â†’ weapons sales surge â†’ infrastructure destroyed â†’ reconstruction contracts awarded â†’ repeat. Every stage generates profits for someone while civilians on all sides pay with their lives.
Until we address the profit motive driving perpetual conflict, peace will remain impossible. Both Israeli and Palestinian civilians deserve better than being used as pawns in other people's money-making schemes.

Nakba Day: For Palestinians, Not Just a Historical Event
While the Zionist project has realized its dream of a homeland in Palestine, the displacement of Palestinians has never ceased. May 15, 1948, is a date etched in infamy for generations of Palestinians who know it as the Nakba, or "the catastrophe," after the declaration of the State of Israel in Palestine.
Palestinians have been commemorating the 72nd anniversary of the Nakba since the Yishuv, the pre-state Jewish community in Palestine, transformed into Israel after the former colonial sponsor, the United Kingdom, left Palestine, which it had invaded and occupied during World War I.

author: @unitedafricancommunitydcau1333
text:
Here's a detailed overview of potential peacekeeping efforts in Palestine and Israel involving France, Pakistan, UK, Jordan, US, and Egypt:

*Peacekeeping Operations:*

Peacekeeping operations in the Israel-Palestine conflict would aim to:
- *Monitor Ceasefires*: Ensure both parties adhere to agreements, reducing violence and hostilities.
- *Provide Humanitarian Aid*: Facilitate access to essential services, such as food, water, and medical care.
- *Support Security and Stability*: Contribute to a secure environment, allowing for economic development and peace negotiations.

*Potential Contributors:*

- *France*: As a permanent member of the UN Security Council, France has a significant role in peacekeeping operations. It has contributed troops to various UN missions and is the 6th largest contributor to the UN peacekeeping budget.
- *Pakistan*: Pakistan has a history of participating in UN peacekeeping operations, with over 9,000 personnel deployed worldwide.
- *UK*: The UK has been involved in various peacekeeping efforts globally and is a significant contributor to the UN peacekeeping budget.
- *Jordan*: Jordan has contributed to UN peacekeeping operations and has a significant role in regional security efforts.
- *US*: The US is a major contributor to UN peacekeeping operations, providing financial and logistical support.
- *Egypt*: Egypt has participated in UN peacekeeping operations and has a significant role in regional security efforts, particularly in the Middle East.

*Challenges and Opportunities:*

- *Complexity of Conflict*: The Israel-Palestine conflict is a longstanding and complex issue, requiring a comprehensive approach to peacekeeping and conflict resolution.
- *International Cooperation*: Collaboration between countries, international organizations, and local stakeholders is crucial for successful peacekeeping efforts.
- *Peacebuilding*: Peacekeeping operations should be accompanied by peacebuilding efforts, focusing on economic development, security sector reform, and social cohesion Â¹ Â².Creating an input action plan to positively impact the lives of people in Lebanon, Syrians,Palestine and Israel requires a thoughtful and multi-faceted approach. Here are some potential steps to consider:

1. _Education and Cultural Exchange_: Establish programs that promote mutual understanding, empathy, and respect between Palestinians and Israelis. This could include student exchanges, cultural events, and educational workshops.

2. _Economic Empowerment_: Support initiatives that foster economic growth and development in both communities. This might involve vocational training, entrepreneurship programs, and small business loans.

3. _Humanitarian Aid_: Provide assistance to those in need, such as refugees, families, and individuals affected by conflict. This could include food, shelter, medical care, and psychological support.

4. _Advocacy and Diplomacy_: Engage in diplomatic efforts to promote peace, understanding, and cooperation between governments and organizations. This might involve supporting peace initiatives, advocating for human rights, and encouraging dialogue.

5. _Community Building_: Foster connections between Palestinians and Israelis through community-based projects, such as joint sports teams, art initiatives, and volunteer work.

A successful plan would require:

1. _Collaboration_: Work with local organizations, governments, and communities to ensure a coordinated and effective approach.

2. _Sustainability_: Develop programs that are long-term and sustainable, rather than short-term fixes.

3. _Empowerment_: Focus on empowering local communities to take ownership of their development and peace-building efforts.

4. _Inclusivity_: Ensure that all initiatives are inclusive and respectful of diverse perspectives, cultures, and identities.

5. _Evaluation_: Regularly assess and evaluate the effectiveness of programs to make adjustments and improvements.

By working together Muslim Countries Western Countries and taking a comprehensive approach, it's possible to create positive change two states resolution end war Gaza and promote peace and  understanding in the region.

author: @nelsonying2898
text:
Does anyone think Pres. Trump may have learned a PR lesson from what happened around the Abraham Accords in his first term? I know itâ€™s a little apples vs oranges, but still itâ€™s got me thinking. 

Putting aside how the Accords legacy might be muddled because of the subsequent Gaza war, I often felt that Trump should have done a better job explaining exactly what his administration did to help get those Accords through. Iâ€™m still not sure to this day. 

Perhaps, back then, his m.o. was just to take all the credit, say itâ€™s the greatest thing ever, maybe not even learn what his administration actually did, and leave it at that. And, some of his supporters in the 2020 election year would just ridiculously parrot â€œdid you know thereâ€™s peace in the Middle East now?â€  

In any case, this time his team is clearly trying to show the details, show him in command, and trying to build on the momentum. 

We shall see what history shows regarding his administrationâ€™s role, the legacy of this ceasefire, and whether foreign policy success will help his ratings at home, but for now the PR seems to be working.

author: @vijdes6687
text: The Gaza ceasefire brokered by President Trump is a fragile and premature pause in conflict rather than a lasting peace. Experts widely agree that though the initial truce and hostage releases offer hope, key issues remain unresolvedâ€”most critically, Hamasâ€™ commitment to disarmament and a permanent ceasefire. Netanyahu was reportedly skeptical about rushing the deal, and many analysts warn that Hamas, deeply entrenched in armed resistance, is unlikely to fully disarm voluntarily. The ceasefireâ€™s second phase, depending on Hamas' full complianceâ€”including releasing all hostages and ceasing hostilitiesâ€”is yet to be fulfilled, and there are ongoing reports of violations and internal executions by Hamas of suspected collaborators. Given these complexities, the current lull carries significant risk of collapse and another round of intense conflict within weeks unless strong enforcement and international mediation persist.

author: @vanburenron
text:
The Bible verses that describe the Antichrist bringing a false peace are Daniel 8:25 and 1 Thessalonians 5:3. Daniel 8:25 states that the Antichrist will "by peace shall destroy many," and 1 Thessalonians 5:3 says, "For when they shall say, Peace and safety; then sudden destruction cometh upon them". Other verses, like Daniel 9:27, describe him making a treaty or covenant with Israel, which he later breaks, marking the halfway point of a seven-year period. 
Daniel 8:25: "And through his policy also he shall cause craft to prosper in his hand; and by peace shall destroy many: he shall also stand up against the Prince of princes; but he shall be broken without hand". 
1 Thessalonians 5:3: "For when they shall say, Peace and safety; then sudden destruction cometh upon them, as travail upon a woman with child; and they shall not escape". 
Daniel 9:27: This verse is often cited as evidence that the Antichrist will make a covenant with many for seven years, and in the middle of that week (at the three-and-a-half-year mark), he will break it.

author: @thefrequencypage
text:
As of today, October 13, 2025, Israel has continued military actions in Gaza despite the ceasefire agreement announced on October 9. 

These actions include airstrikes, artillery shelling, and restrictions on civilian movement, which multiple sources have reported as violations of the ceasefire terms.

Real-Time Ceasefire Violations by Israel (October 9â€“13, 2025)

Continued Bombing After Ceasefire Announcement

Gaza City and Khan Younis were bombarded overnight following the ceasefire declaration.

Israeli quadcopters reportedly dropped bombs on civilians in Gaza City.

At least nine people were killed in these attacks, according to health officials.

Civilian Movement Blocked

Israeli tanks blocked al-Rasheed Road, preventing displaced Palestinians from returning north.

Live rounds and artillery were intermittently fired at civilians attempting to move.

Ongoing Strikes Despite Celebrations

Even as Palestinians celebrated the ceasefire, Israeli strikes killed 10 people, including two aid seekers, and injured nearly 50 others over a 24-hour period.

U.S. Troop Deployment to Monitor Violations
The U.S. is sending 200 troops to Israel to help monitor the ceasefire and coordinate humanitarian aid.

A multinational taskforce will be established to oversee compliance, including forces from Egypt, Qatar, Turkey, and the UAE.

Ceasefire Terms and Context

The October 9 ceasefire is part of a U.S.-brokered peace plan aiming to end the two-year war.

It includes:

Immediate halt to hostilities

Release of hostages and prisoners

Surge of humanitarian aid

Phased Israeli military withdrawal

Despite these terms, Israeli actions have not ceased, and Hamas has accused Israel of manipulating prisoner release lists, further straining the agreement.

Sources

Middle East Eye  
Reported Israeli bombings in Gaza City and Khan Younis after the ceasefire announcement  
Date: October 9, 2025

Democracy Now  
Covered Israeli strikes that killed 10 and injured 50 despite the ceasefire  
Date: October 9, 2025

CBS News  
Reported on the ceasefire signing and continued military actions  
Date: October 13, 2025

Human Rights Watch  
Emphasized that the ceasefire must lead to justice and humanitarian access  
Date: October 9, 2025

MSN via Reuters  
Reported that the United States is sending 200 troops to monitor ceasefire violations  
Date: October 10, 2025

The Hindu  
Covered condemnation of Israeli actions by Tamil Nadu's legislative assembly  
Date: October 8, 2025

GovFacts  
Explained the terms and implementation timeline of the ceasefire agreement  
Date: October 10, 2025

Tempo  
Reported Hamas accusations that Israel violated the ceasefire by altering the prisoner release list  
Date: October 13, 2025

The Week  
Covered Israel's claim that Hamas breached the ceasefire by returning only four bodies of hostages  
Date: October 13, 2025

Times of Israel  
Reported Hamas statements that the United States guaranteed the war had ended indefinitely  
Date: October 9, 2025

Al Jazeera  
Published a map showing Israeli withdrawal zones under the ceasefire agreement  
Date: October 9, 2025

author: @thefrequencypage
text:
Peace Mongers vs. War Mongers: 
The Theater of Power and the Machinery Beneath

In every empire, the greatest threat to war is peace.

Peace Mongers those who advocate for diplomacy, transparency, and demilitarization
donâ€™t just challenge policy. 

They threaten the entire scaffolding of the war economy: the arms contracts, the surveillance budgets, the covert operations, and the psychological conditioning of fear. 

They disrupt the narrative that justifies endless conflict. And that makes them dangerous.

Superpowers Need Supervillains

Every â€œsuperpowerâ€ requires a â€œsupervillain.â€ Not for defense, but for performance. 

The villain provides the moral justification for expansion, espionage, and economic extraction. 

This is not a new game; itâ€™s a ritual. 

A rotating cast of enemies, each tailored to the momentâ€™s needs: communists, terrorists, hackers, cartels, rogue states. 

The labels change, but the function remains.
This theater is not just ideological. Itâ€™s financial.

The Real Economy: Espionage, Laundering, and Syndicates

Beneath the surface of diplomacy lies a shadow economy:

Espionage networks operate across borders, often indistinguishable from organized crime.

Real estate becomes a laundering mechanism opaque, high-value, and globally tradable.

Banking institutions, knowingly or not, facilitate the flow: shell companies, offshore accounts, and regulatory blind spots.

Organized crime syndicates serve dual roles both tools and scapegoats. 

Their operations often mirror those of state actors.

This is not conspiracy. Itâ€™s infrastructure.
Symbolic Warfare and Psychological Conditioning

The war economy is not just built on bombs itâ€™s built on symbols:

Peace is framed as weakness.

Surveillance is sold as safety.

Dissent is pathologized or criminalized.

Media narratives reinforce these frames, shaping public perception and silencing opposition. 

The result is a population conditioned to accept militarism as normal, even noble.

Strategic Implications

For activists, analysts, and civic architects, the challenge is clear:

Expose the symbolic scaffolding reveal how narratives are constructed and weaponized.

Map the financial flows trace the laundering mechanisms and complicit institutions.

Design counter-theaters.rituals, stories, and frameworks that elevate peace as strength, transparency as power.

Peace Mongers must become architects not just of critique, but of alternative systems.

author: @Truth...
text:
The following is a complete refutation of the accusations of genocide made in recent years.

The current death toll in the Gaza War is about three percent of the Gaza Stripâ€™s population. [1] This is lower than the CIA estimate for the number of people who wouldâ€™ve been born in the area during the duration, as they assigned the area a population growth estimate of 2.02% in 2024. [2] This means that the people with Gazan heritage (both those who stayed and those who emigrated) may have had little to no real population decrease.

To put these casualty figures in a historical context, the UN estimates around 92% of Gazaâ€™s residential buildings to have been damaged or destroyed. [3] This means that a war which has broken 92% of the homes over nearly two years has failed to kill 97% of the population in the same time frame. For comparison, the Atomic Heritage Foundation cites General Curtis LeMay as assuming 20% of North Koreaâ€™s population to have died in the Korean War, while CFR education says the same conflict destroyed 85% of North Koreaâ€™s buildings without making a breakdown between different types of buildings. [4][5] This means that while destroying or damaging a potentially higher share of Gazaâ€™s buildings than UN forces destroyed of North Koreaâ€™s buildings, Israel has killed a far smaller share of Gazaâ€™s population.

Furthermore, Reuters notes that â€œThe Palestinian Health Ministry figures do not differentiate between civilians and Hamas combatants, who do not wear formal uniform or carry separate identification.â€ [1] This indicates that Hamas is not reasonably doing what it can to protect the people under its rule from succumbing to the conflict. In fact, it does the opposite, with a 2019 NATO report finding that it engages in the following activities:

â€œFiring rockets, artillery, and mortars from or in proximity to heavily populated civilian areas, often from or near facilities which should be protected according to the Geneva Convention (e.g. schools, hospitals, or mosques).

Locating military or security-related infrastructures such as HQs, bases, armouries, access routes, lathes, or defensive positions within or in proximity to civilian areas.

Protecting terroristsâ€™ houses and military facilities, or rescuing terrorists who were besieged or warned by the IDF.

Combating the IDF from or in proximity to residential and commercial areas, including using civilians for intelligence gathering missions.â€ [6] Even with this, Hamas militants are still around a third of deaths in the Gaza Strip. [1]

As you can see, the low death rate, especially in relation to other wars or to Gazaâ€™s own birth rate, coupled with Hamasâ€™s practices in aggressing this war and doing the opposite of protecting its civilians during the course, proves the genocide accusations to be entirely false.

[1] Al-Mughrabi, Nidal, and Emma Farge. â€œHow Many Palestinians Has Israelâ€™s Gaza Offensive Killed?â€Â Reuters, 29 July 2025,Â http://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/how-many-palestinians-has-israels-gaza-offensive-killed-2025-03-24/.

[2]Â Gaza Strip - the World Factbook.Â http://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/gaza-strip. Last updated August 22, 2025.

[4] â€œThe Korean War - Nuclear Museum.â€Â Nuclear Museum,Â The Korean War - Nuclear Museum.

author: @ralphhebgen7067
text:
I would love to know more about the driving forces behind this deal. Here is my take:

- Israel has risen to the incontestable premier military force in the region. The October Hamas atrocities have pushed Israel over the edge. In the first, say 14 or so months of their Gaza campaign the IDF have masterfully reduced the operational capacity of Hamas to near-zero. Hamas was aware of this.
- In the final 4 months of the campaign Israel was beginning to look unhinged, less focussed strategically, and more erratic, to the point that accusations of genocide were starting to look more believable than in the initial months. A culmination point was the attack on Qatar, an independent sovereign state with no direct involvement in the conflict.
- Trumpâ€™s threat to support Israel unconditionally if Hamas did not surrender, seen together with Israelâ€™s increasing radicalisation, sent alarm signals to Qatar and Saudi Arabia, who started putting pressure on Hamas lest the conflict would finally broaden to the wider Middle East
- Details of the plan look to be taken directly out of the blueprint of Tony Blairâ€™s Good Friday agreement. 

So, probably as an over-simplification, Trump was the brawn, Blair the brain. It took not just force to get Hamas to agree, but the threat of an unpredictable US president who cannot justifiably be seen as rational to get this over the line. The question is now whether this mix of drivers is suitable for the next phase. The next phase must be constructive, rather than destructive. As long as Trump does not have the peace prize, he still has skin in the game, he still is motivated to act. But as it is just brawn he brings to the table, I have no confidence that the next phase can be more than all the other phases we have seen since 1948. Sustainable peace can only happen if the Palestinians have a state of their own, and they cannot have that until Israel withdraws from the West Bank, and the Palestinians give up on the right of return. These are incisive compromises both parties have to make. As they will not be made, even this breakthrough is likely to usher in merely the next period of uneasy peace, and then things will explode again.

author: @RagingBull-go7lo
text: As an Armenian-American with half of my family members from Lebanon, I have a story I would like to share here. The decades-long conflict has and continues to affect Lebanon; my father, aunt, and grandparents all experienced and saw the country change because of it. In Beirut, they lived near the Palestinian refugee camps, which were originally populated by Armenians fleeing the 1915 Genocide. The majority of the Palestinians in Lebanon originate from the towns and villages in present-day Israel that were depopulated as a result of the 1947-1949 Palestine war, aka Nakba, and their presence in Lebanon would serve as one of the contributing factors to the Lebanese Civil War (1975-1991). My grandmother (died in 2021), who was 20 in 1948 when Israel was established, said that once that happened, the country changed completely. Also, when she was home alone, gunmen from those camps showed up at her front door with the intent to kill her, and despite her being able to tell them that she meant no harm, she never recovered from that experience. I want the conflict to end with the two-state solution to finally become a reality, which is an Israeli and Palestinian State living side-by-side in peace, and all of the settlements in the West Bank will need to be evacuated, with them either disbanded or repopulated with Palestinians who were displaced.

author: @KT-dj4iy
text:
0:05 _â€This week, that apt description led to success.â€_

Why is everyone, even brains like Fareed, succumbing to a _post hoc ergo propter hoc_ fallacy?
We know that Trump is transactional.
And we know that there has been success in Gaza.
But we do _not_ know that the former _caused_ the latter.
Correlation is not necessarily causation.

Furthermore, even if we _could_ make that causal connection, we cannot tell if Trump _intended_ to have that impact, or if, rather, he was trying to achieve something else and the Gaza thing just happened by accident.

author: @Mogthrasir1989
text:
This deal will collapse before the end of the year, and again because of who was in that room.  The transaction was between old men who have a vested interest in preserving their status as heads of their respective factions, regardless of ideological considerations at this point:  the Palestinians are in an existential crisis of daily bombardment, Netanyahu has to at some point look like he's willing to deal in some way to get hostages or end the bloodshed or else face an inevitable Vietnam-style "malaise" at home.  The people waiting in the wings behind Netanyahu, and especially Hamas, did not agree to these terms - and there is no guarantee of how long the respective leaders can maintain discipline amongst their followers.

For that matter, spare a thought for the representatives of roughly half of the Palestinians - Fatah - who represent the West Bank.  They weren't at the table, and they sure as heck didn't agree to anything.  Did Hamas just trade away concessions to Israel that Fatah isn't comfortable with?  These are the problems you have when the "state" you have constructed on paper is a fiction; not truly self-governing or sovereign.  Just a convenient invasion target for your troops when you want to "Get 'Em Back", because it sounds better than what you'd really be doing - which is rolling tanks into something between a Native Reservation or an enforced Ghetto.

And even if it does hold, and let's say for the moment that the bright shining future that everyone supposedly wants comes to pass.  In ten years, if there is a truly sovereign and self-governing Arab Palestine State bordering Israel, do you REALLY think the Israelis will let them have a standing army?  Secure their own borders?  Allow or disallow arms trade across their frontiers?  Pull the other one.  Israel will never allow an independent Palestinian state to exist.

author: @jfrancobelge
text: We can only rejoice in the liberations and the halt, even temporary, of the bombings, but then nothing is certain. A ceasefire is not a peace treaty, just a pause in the war. In Israel, Netanyahu and the Likud are still in power, and they are not pacifists. In Gaza, Hamas needed a breather, but they are still there too, and they show no real willingness to give way either. As for their disarmament, that is wishful thinking. So, peace or a resumption of hostilities? IF moderates come to power in Gaza and Jerusalem... IF the respective allies of the two camps apply enough pressure to calm things down (and they give themselves the means to do so)... IF hatred does not prevail over reason... time will tell. And then there's the matter of Gaza, but what about the West Bank, the sometimes violent encroachment of its territory by extremist settlers with the at least passive complicity of Netanyahu? That's not going to ease relations between the two peoples. In short, for the moment it's far too early to talk about peace.

Palestine was never an empty land â€” it was home to people with roots, families, and dreams.
Yet, the great powers of history â€” the same ones that speak of â€œhuman rightsâ€ and â€œpeaceâ€ â€” were among those who helped remove these people from their land.
France, Britain, and America once drew borders with the blood of nations, and now they speak of justice as if they were never part of the wound.

Iâ€™m not seeking hatred, but a simple truth:
How can there be real peace without justice?
How can we forget those displaced, those lost, and those who still dream of returning home?

True peace does not come from political agreements â€” it comes from recognizing injustice and correcting it.
Until that day comes, Palestine will remain the story of a people who never gave up.
